body:
A couple of diffs that might need special attention

What is `spark-kernel` here?

```
--- a/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/dependencies/IvyDependencyDownloader.scala
+++ b/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/dependencies/IvyDependencyDownloader.scala
@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@
  * limitations under the License.
  */

-package com.ibm.spark.dependencies
+package org.apache.toree.dependencies

 import java.io.{File, PrintStream}
 import java.net.URL
@@ -87,7 +87,7 @@ class IvyDependencyDownloader(repositoryUrl: String, baseDirectory: String)
     ivyFile.deleteOnExit()

     val md = DefaultModuleDescriptor.newDefaultInstance(
-      ModuleRevisionId.newInstance("com.ibm.spark", "spark-kernel", "working")
+      ModuleRevisionId.newInstance("org.apache.toree", "spark-kernel", "working")
     )


```

What do we do about 3rd party magics and the package? (i.e. Brunel Magic)

```

--- a/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/magic/MagicLoader.scala
+++ b/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/magic/MagicLoader.scala
@@ -14,12 +14,12 @@
  * limitations under the License.
  */

-package com.ibm.spark.magic
+package org.apache.toree.magic

 import java.net.{URL, URLClassLoader}

 import com.google.common.reflect.ClassPath
-import com.ibm.spark.magic.dependencies.DependencyMap
+import org.apache.toree.magic.dependencies.DependencyMap

 import scala.reflect.runtime.{universe => runtimeUniverse}
 import scala.collection.JavaConversions._
@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@ class MagicLoader(
   urls: Array[URL] = Array(),
   parentLoader: ClassLoader = null
 ) extends URLClassLoader(urls, parentLoader) {
-  private val magicPackage = "com.ibm.spark.magic.builtin"
+  private val magicPackage = "org.apache.toree.magic.builtin"

   /**
    * Checks whether a magic with a given name, implementing a given interface,
diff --git a/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/magic/dependencies/DependencyMap.scala b/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/magic/dependencies/DependencyMap.scala
index f641a50..1f36e2b 100644


```
Fixes https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-247
We've completed all the Todo's for this PR. This is ready to merge.
@lbustelo, all good to go.

Just noticed that installing Toree this way, there are two assembly jars under `/usr/local/share/jupyter/kernels/toree/lib/`.
- toree-kernel-assembly-0.1.0.dev1-SNAPSHOT.jar
- toree-kernel-assembly-0.1.0.dev2-SNAPSHOT.jar

Are both of those supposed to appear? This was with a fresh install on a new machine. I ran `sudo pip install toree` followed by `sudo jupyter toree install`.

Also, if we are going to create the `kernel.json` for them, would it make sense to create one per language we support? You're installing everything after all.

Have labels like:
- Toree (Scala 2.10.4)
- Toree (PySpark)
- Toree (SparkR)
- Toree (SparkSQL)

I think it's a good idea since we've started to see a couple of folks use PySpark and it would give more presence to the other languages that the kernel offers, so people don't continue to think that the kernel only supports Scala.

I think this change would be in the scope of this PR, too. No sense opening another PR just to add these options.
LGTM
merged by cherrypick
closing in favor of #6
taking a look at this now

Tried a couple of dependencies and different repositories and all worked fine. 

I saw that dependencies are getting installed under `/tmp/.ivy2/https/repo1.maven.org/maven2/io/netty/netty/3.6.3.Final/netty-3.6.3.Final.jar`. Is it fair to say that we still do not have dependency isolation with `AddDeps` between kernel instances?

Potential JIRAs that can be resolved by this
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-184
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-169
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-246

Do we want to look into this under the same PR? Or open another issue? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-169?focusedCommentId=15104588&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15104588

FYI, I read that using Coursier for resolution/downloading over standard sbt has a large increase in performance. Might be worth adding the plugin for us to see if it helps with Toree dependency resolution/downloading, especially when running automated build/test.
Lets handle the location of the deps in a separate PR. I opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-261. We should just go ahead and get that work done asap since this is fresh.
@chipsenkbeil Can you review this?
@lbustelo yeah, I'll take care of it.
Ran through demo. LGTM.
Merged!
fixes https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-258

Still need to add tests.

@chipsenkbeil Can you take a quick look? Most importantly, I had to add support to save off `_lastKernelMessage` in the Comm messages.
Tests are in. removing the WIP status
@lbustelo looked it over and everything checks out to me.
@chipsenkbeil so no issues with storing the comm request as parents?

@lbustelo, I don't think so. We just use that to allow you to keep track of a specific parent header when creating streaming messages. That's kept in a closure with the stream once started, so I don't think a comm message will hurt it. If you want to be safe, create another global that holds on to the last comm kernel message instead of execution request kernel message.
Will come back to this one later.

So currently running "jupyter toree install" only install one kernel (scala). @chipsenkbeil as you mentioned in comment, it would be nice to have it installed kernel for all the supported languages. 

In general, in your experience which is a better way to run pyspark or SparkR using Toree or directly using normal python and R interpreter. Also if you say Toree can you please explain reason.

Adding one last feature I think is useful (specifying a "suggested" priority for plugins) and refactoring what is returned from firing events (a map of plugin/method to result instead of just a sequence of results).
Tested via `make jupyter`, `make dist` and using Travis to run "bare bones."
Ok.. merged
taking a look at this now

Added `TOREE_RESOLUTION_VERBOSITY` so we can reduce how much resolution/downloading stuff is logged. Should be much cleaner output for Travis (kept standard logging for normal builds, Travis uses 0, which is minimal logging).

Squashed and rebased.
@lbustelo I would say that this is the more important of the two PRs to merge first. It will be much faster to rebase the Coursier than this one.
All looks good. merged
It does behave faster. It is great when using `%AddDeps` in the notebook. merged!
Closes https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-270
+1 for scala 2.11
@chipsenkbeil or @Lull3rSkat3r Please review

Looks fine to me. Already tried the badge from your fork and it launched a notebook. Just to make sure, the intention is for it to launch a Python3 kernel whose notebook contains a link to the notebook listing with the example Toree notebook, right?

Yeah. I think that would be best. No need to start a Toree kernel just for markdown. 

Gino B.

> On Mar 7, 2016, at 3:59 PM, Chip Senkbeil notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Looks fine to me. Already tried the badge from your fork and it launched a notebook. Just to make sure, the intention is for it to launch a Python3 kernel whose notebook contains a link to the notebook listing with the example Toree notebook, right?
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Cool. I'll merge this one tomorrow.
+1.  Any timeline for this, or anything we can help with to unblock it?

I don't think this should impede our 0.1.0 release plan. 

Gino B.

> On Mar 8, 2016, at 11:45 AM, Chip Senkbeil notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @leifwalsh, we're going to have to figure out how the REPL works for 2.11 in terms of how class files are shipped over to Spark clusters. Previously, this was done with an entirely separate HTTP server, but it looks like they might have merged that in to the SparkContext's class server for 2.11.
> 
> I'm sure that there are several tests that are broken by this and will need to have Scala 2.10 and Scala 2.11 versions in the same manner that this branch provides implementations of the Scala interpreter class for 2.10 and 2.11.
> 
> @lbustelo, did we want this done before the first binary release?
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
@chipsenkbeil ok, sounds like more work than I thought.  Should we expect this will take more than a couple of weeks, and roll our internal stuff back to 2.10 in the meantime?
Based on the comments from @chipsenkbeil, I would think that this would take several weeks and be a very delicate process. Lots of parts to test. I would roll back to 2.10.
@Lull3rSkat3r, is this good to go? Do you want me to look over it and merge if ready? Or is there still something to be done?
I needed to rebase which I just did. Also, @lbustelo had some input, so wait for him.
@Lull3rSkat3r See if this works for you in terms of debugging and my comments on PR #11
![sharedsqlcontext](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2474841/13800436/3e8d9106-eaf7-11e5-9a97-141634fc70d7.gif)

@chipsenkbeil This is still WIP, but check out what I had to do to get this going. Considering these changes, I feel like we have many unnecessary methods in [Interpreter.scala](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/interpreter/Interpreter.scala). It seems that `bindSparkContext` and `bindSqlContext` will not be necessary, and rather something that should be API in `kernel` and Interpreters can get a hold during the `init` call.
/cc @parente

@lbustelo, I agree completely with unnecessary methods in the interpreter. Initializing using the kernel object was a goal that Brian and I discussed and it looks like it makes more sense now, although you still have issues like lazily starting a SparkContext (and SQLContext) being bound to the interpreter later (more Scala than PySpark). Of course, if interpreters were made plugins, they could receive a SparkContext/SQLContext event when those were created and bind the variables at that point.

There are methods in the interpreter that are more interpreter-specific (class server uri stemming from the Scala 2.10 interpreter only), have a hideous API (interpret call's return value), or duplicate/confuse other methods (start vs init). Cleaning those up would be excellent.
Looks good to me!
@lbustelo, push is changed and all good to go.
Ok, can one of you merge? Remember to rebase or cherry pick. I think Luciano pushes something straight to master and I don't have it on my branch.

I made some slight changes in how the `SPARK_OPTS` are merged. Instead of combining the values of `__TOREE_SPARK_OPTS__` and `SPARK_OPTS` they will be used in order of precedence. `SPARK_OPTS` will be used before `__TOREE_SPARK_OPTS__`. I did this to simplify how people will have to reason about ordering of their arguments, and to simplify `run.sh` :wink:.

I tested the following enumerations and I have recorded the behvior, which IMO is correct:
- This just starts the kernel with no extra arguments to spark

``` bash
# Define no spark opts
jupyter toree install --interpreters=PySpark,SQL,Scala,SparkR
jupyter notebook --ip=* --no-browser'
```
- This starts the kernel and waits for a debugger to connect

``` bash
# Define install spark_opts
jupyter toree install --spark_opts="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=trace -agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005" --interpreters=PySpark,SQL,Scala,SparkR
jupyter notebook --ip=* --no-browser'
```
- This starts the kernel and I only see warning logs

``` bash
# Define install spark_opts and SPARK_OPTS
jupyter toree install --spark_opts="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=trace -agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005" --interpreters=PySpark,SQL,Scala,SparkR 
SPARK_OPTS="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=warn" jupyter notebook --ip=* --no-browser'
```
- This starts the kernel and I only see warning logs

``` bash
# Define only SPARK_OPTS
jupyter toree install --interpreters=PySpark,SQL,Scala,SparkR 
SPARK_OPTS="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=warn" jupyter notebook --ip=* --no-browser'
```

There is a slight hack I had to do. For the case where there are no options passed I was receving an error. This was caused by an empty string being interpreted as the class file to load. I fixed this by adding in the `--driver-class-path` option @chipsenkbeil and I are adding for the magics work. I am open for a better solution, but am lacking the bash-fu to get there. 

Any feedback @lbustelo @chipsenkbeil ?
Spoke with you in person. Hack sounds fine since we'll always have that option of `--driver-class-path` in place.
I'm going to rebase it

There may be a missed testcase which better resembles my docker run

```
# Define a multi JVM property --driver-java-options through the SPARK_OPTS env var
jupyter toree install --spark_opts="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=warn" --interpreters=PySpark,SQL,Scala,SparkR 
SPARK_OPTS="--driver-java-options=-Dlog4j.logLevel=trace -agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005" jupyter notebook --ip=* --no-browser'
```
@dongjoon-hyun, is this all good to go?  I can merge if it is ready.

Oh, yes. That's all for me. Please merge this.
Thank you for review, @Lull3rSkat3r !

Oh, it's interesting. It fails with the following errors. Is there something wrong?

```
[info] Tests: succeeded 233, failed 0, canceled 0, ignored 0, pending 0
[info] All tests passed.
[error] (toree-client/test:test) sbt.TestsFailedException: Tests unsuccessful
[error] Total time: 314 s, completed Mar 24, 2016 6:00:28 PM
```

Nothing is wrong. We're using Akka extensively and have test timeouts. Travis tends to be a little too slow at times, even with our scaled timeouts, which is why these tests occasionally have hiccups. We have plans to improve testing performance such that these issues don't happen as regularly (or at all). If you want it to pass, you'll have to keep closing and reopening until they do so, but I'm content merging this as-is since it's just altering comments.
Oh, thank you. Yep, please merge this. It's just about comment changing.

@dongjoon-hyun, even though it's just comments, do you mind rebasing on top of master? Only difference is the changes from your other PR I just merged in. We're trying to keep a clean(er) commit log going forward.
Thank you for merging, @chipsenkbeil !
@dongjoon-hyun, thanks for the contribution. :wink:
Oh, sure, no problem!
I rebased this to the master again.
@dongjoon-hyun, thanks! @Lull3rSkat3r will be getting to this one soon.

It's my honor. I've started using Toree personally a few days ago. I like Toree.
(Before that, I've used Zeppelin.)
Merged, thanks for the contribution @dongjoon-hyun!
Thank you for merging, @Lull3rSkat3r and @chipsenkbeil .
Did you guys test the [brunel](https://github.com/Brunel-Visualization/Brunel) magic?
@lbustelo, we have not tried the brunel magic. Will try that and let you know.
@Lull3rSkat3r and I tested the magic and it did not work. This scenario is interesting because it is a plugin added using `%%AddJar`.
We are probably missing something in `AddJar` or our logic for backwards compatiability in `MagicManager` is flawed. Will look into it and let you know.

Ok, last change should cover your use case, @lbustelo. You will need to specify the parameter like this for a command line arg:

```
--spark_opts='--driver-java-options="-Dlog4j.logLevel=trace -agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005"'
```

Or like this for an environment variable:

```
SPARK_OPTS='--driver-java-options="-Dlog4j.logLevel=trace -agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005"'
```
Branch is rebased and should is good to merge once someone reviews it.

So the problem is the `AddJar` magic did not maintain the backwards compatibility of adding the jar to the classpath. The `findMagic` method in `MagicManager`  is also incorrect. This method is only called in the backwards compatible method but is searching through a list of plugins, which the old magics will not be. 

We will basically need to bring back the old `MagicLoader` class to maintain the compatibility. It might be easier to just mixin that behavior to `MagicManager` and remove it once we want to no longer maintain compatibility.

Another option is to just abandon the old compatibility and offer a migration guide from Spark Kernel to Toree. These changes would be minimal, similar to what was done in the magics for this PR ( e.g. [LsMagic](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/pull/19/files#diff-452e44f32062cc53a123077b54453ad7L23) ).

@Lull3rSkat3r we search against plugins because any magic compiled against Toree will now be a plugin. We should not be supporting magics compiled against a pre-release Toree. For Brunel, if the backwards compatibility works, it should be as simple as updating their dependencies to Toree 0.1.0 (interface remains the same due to backwards compatibility).

The compatibility was meant to handle the case where they did not implement the plugin methods using annotations. All magics should now be loaded as plugins (when compiled against Toree 0.1.0), but old magics will still be executed directly instead of through the event messages.

Right, so I think we need to define more thoroughly what it means for a magic to be backwards compatible and what we are going to support. That is where I was getting confused. 

So here are the levels of backwards compatibility I see:
1. Magics being under the package 'com.ibm.spark.kernel'
2. Magics which are not plugins, but under 'org.apache.toree' (Brunel magic)

As @chipsenkbeil alluded above, the second item in the list is technically not a valid magic, since there has not yet been a release. Now the question remains about the first item.

IMO there is no backwards compatibility to support because all magics will and should need to be recompiled against the first release of toree because of the package changing. Since there is a binary incompatibility in that regard, I don't think there is much sense in supporting older styles. The only way this would make sense is if we were going to continue to look in the `com.ibm.spark.kernel` package for magics.

 I vote we put a PR into the Brunel magic repo and remove the backwards compatibility code in MagicManager. Thoughts @chipsenkbeil and @lbustelo?

I'm fine with pushing a PR to Brunel.

When I think about backwards compat, I was not thinking about supporting the "com.ibm.spark" package. I was thinking that meant supporting the old way of authoring magic that required the class to be in a set package name, and that package name would be `org.apache.toree`. 

I'm now leaning to completely removing the back compat support. We have an opportunity here to simplify.
I'm reviewing

I tested passing the multiple `--driver-java-options` as explained above. I used docker `-e` and it worked.

Now, on installing by default all the interpreters... I think that we should only install what we think is satisfactory working. Here are some of the issues that I've found when scala is not the default interpreter.
1. Magics are not handled at all. This means that from a SQL default interpreter I cannot add data to a context using any of the other languages supported. That makes the SQL interpreter very limited.
2. If we install PySpark and SparkR in a default run of `jupyter toree install` as stand-alone kernels, are we sure that they can satisfactory perform the majority of what a user could accomplish with the Python kernel in jupyter or IRkernel? If the answer is no, then I think that by default I would only install the Scala Kernel but keep the `--interpreter` flag to install the other kernels. If yes, then I guess I'm ok with. 

I will just offer that in the context of the `all-spark-notebook` docker image, I don't see us ever installing Toree as multiple kernels and only installing the Scala one. It will make selecting a notebook confusing when it comes to R and Python.
@lbustelo removed -v on sbt and got rid of backwards compatibility code.
Ran streaming demo and all looked good. Will merge.
@lbustelo, will rebase this and ping when it is ready.
I tested the install of kernels and I think it looks good. It is the right choice to only install Scala by default. Let me know if you are done and I'll merge.
@lbustelo rebased and good to go!
Thanks to @Lull3rSkat3r for spotting the missing line of code that got lost during my merge. All tests should pass now.
LGTM.
@chipsenkbeil I think I addressed all your code comments. I'm going to finish up the example notebook and that would be the last part of this PR. Are there any other code comments?
LGTM

Worked with @chipsenkbeil.

@Lull3rSkat3r can you take a quick look and merge?
